conclusion: To determine the ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for particles A and B during their deceleration phases, we need to analyze the slopes of the lines representing their velocities during these phases.
Particle A: The deceleration phase occurs between t = t_0 and t = 3t_0. During this time, the velocity decreases from 2v_0 to 0.
Particle B: The deceleration phase occurs between t = 5t_0 and t = 6t_0. During this time, the velocity decreases from v_0 to 0.

premise: The acceleration a_A is given by the slope of the velocity-time graph during the deceleration phase.
The magnitude of the acceleration for particle A is |a_A| = |-v_0 / t_0|.
The acceleration a_B is given by the slope of the velocity-time graph during its deceleration phase.
The magnitude of the acceleration for particle B is |a_B| = |-v_0 / t_0|.
The ratio of the magnitudes of the accelerations for particles A and B is |a_A| / |a_B|.
